lawl_temp:

Challenge: fuckoff no one gives a shit

If you look at the content of programming forums on MITB it’s quite shit - it’s mostly noobs asking stupid questions. Nothing interesting. Then I see people like you who are supposedly “Java gurus” and “C++ coders”. I thought, let’s throw two challenges at you. This one was incredibly easy, the other one was a bit tricky. I’m convinced that these challenges were not completed not because people were lazy, but because they did not have sufficient knowledge.

To sum it up: go fuck off youself, little retard.

item.source: [C++] Challenge: Modify a private data member

item.title: [C++] Challenge: Modify a private data member
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Due to no one posting a solution I’ll post mine. The solution here is to make use of the default assignment operator that makes a copy of all data members.

#include <iostream>

class A
{
public:
	A(unsigned int i)
	{
		m_i = i;
	}

	~A(void)
	{

	}

	void print(void)
	{
		std::cout << "A " << m_i << std::endl;
	}

private:
	unsigned int m_i;
};

int main(void)
{
	A a(200);
	a = A(1000); //Change the value of a.m_i to 1000.
	a.print();

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return 0;
}

[quote=“t4, post:2, topic:425609”] friend int main(void);
:|[/quote]

This would require modifying class A, so it’s forbidden.

Read full topic

item.source: [C++] Challenge: Modify a private data member

item.title: [C++] Challenge: Modify a private data member
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

#include <iostream>

class A
{
public:
	A(unsigned int i)
	{
		m_i = i;
	}

	~A(void)
	{

	}

	void print(void)
	{
		std::cout << "A " << m_i << std::endl;
	}

private:
	unsigned int m_i;
};

int main(void)
{
	A a(200);

	//Change the value of a.m_i to 1000.

	a.print();

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return 0;
}

You must modify a.m_i and set it’s value to 1000, then a.print() is expected to output ‘A 1000’.

Rules:

  1. Write only standard C++ code.
  2. Do not modify class A.
  3. Raw data modification using force-casting is forbidden, as shown below - it would be too easy.
unsigned int* m_i = reinterpret_cast<unsigned int*>(&a);
*m_i = 1000;

EDIT:
Posted the solution.

Read full topic
